Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1:

Dear [Recipient],

I am writing to refer a patient, [Patient Name], who has been experiencing a dull constant headache on waking, 2-3 episodes of vomiting, and photophobia. The patient has no fevers, rash, cough, shortness of breath, or visual disturbance. While the headache is still present, the photophobia has subsided. Upon examination, I have diagnosed the patient with migraines, but I am uncertain whether we need to carry out an LP. If this is required, it will have to be under general anesthesia.

I would appreciate it if you could review this patient at your earliest convenience.

Best regards,

[Your Name]

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 2:

Dear Dr. Neurologist,

I am writing to refer my patient, [Patient Name], who was admitted with a tonic-clonic seizure and has been diagnosed with Generalized idiopathic epilepsy and epileptic syndromes. [Patient Name] does not have a history of seizures, and their recent seizure has caused decreased consciousness and left-sided weakness.

[Patient Name] also has a diagnosis of Alzheimer's dementia, which further complicates their condition. I have consulted with a neuro SPR in Southampton, who has reviewed images and sees no clear evidence of obstruction. However, possible hydrocephalus ex-vacuo has been identified and is scheduled to be discussed at the neurosurgical meeting today.

Given [Patient Name]'s advanced age and diagnosis of Alzheimer's dementia, it has been suggested that a lumbar puncture be performed to measure the opening pressure and get an in-house neurological opinion. I am hopeful that your expertise can provide additional insight into [Patient Name]'s condition and aid in providing the necessary diagnostic and treatment steps.

Thank you for your attention to this matter, and I look forward to your involvement in [Patient Name]'s care.

Sincerely,

Given his history, we think it would be best to have you review and potentially take over his care. Your expertise in neurology would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you for your assistance in this matter.

Sincerely,

[Your name]

Question: Referral letter: Referral Letter 1:

Dear Specialist,

I am referring Ms. Cooper, who was admitted to our facility with left-sided flank pain and dysuria. She was diagnosed with UTI and treated accordingly. During her stay, she reported left-leg pain and sporadic sensory changes, in addition to left-sided facial weakness and sensory loss. We have initiated her on gabapentin for her neuropathic pain and intend to titrate its dosage depending on its effectiveness. As her attending physician, I believe it would be best to refer her to a specialist for further evaluation and management of her condition, given the ongoing symptoms.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

Dr. XYZ

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 2:

Dear Dr. Massey,

We are writing to refer a 17-year-old patient to your clinic with a diagnosis of G40.3 - Generalized idiopathic epilepsy and epileptic syndromes. The patient had a first episode of seizure at work on December 10, 2017. Witnesses reported that the patient's eyes rolled back, became rigid, and fell backwards, shaking arms and legs for two minutes. There was tongue biting, but no incontinence. The patient had another similar episode one minute later.

During the post-ictal phase, the patient could not remember going to work. Later that night, the patient attended a party and consumed excess alcohol. Witnesses stated that the patient knocked back whilst sitting on the curb and hit her head on the pavement. There was no immediate loss of consciousness.

We believe that your expertise in managing patients with epilepsy will be invaluable in treating this patient. We are confident that under your guidance, the patient will receive the best possible care. Please let us know if you require any further information. We have arranged for the patient to see you as soon as possible.

Thank you for your assistance.

Sincerely,

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1: 

Dear Dr. Burn, 

I am writing to refer to you an 83-year-old man who was admitted to our hospital with a collapsed state and confusion on 19-1-18. Upon admission, he was treated for encephalitis and was later admitted to ICU after his condition deteriorated. Currently, he is diagnosed with Pneumonia, unspecified organism and is showing signs of neurological and functional recovery. Due to his previously independent lifestyle, we are concerned about his complete recovery and would like your input on his progress. Thank you for your time and expertise in this matter. 

Sincerely, 

Dr. Page

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 2:

Dear Specialist,

I am writing to refer a patient of mine, a 54 year old lady who has had a 3-52 history of low back pain after falling out of bed onto her back. She experienced reduced mobility since then. She has also reported a 2-3-7 history of reduced sensation in bilateral feet, and pain in both groins. In addition, she has a longstanding urinary incontinence and has reported incomplete bowel emptying. Her previous fall was 3-12 ago onto her right side and lead to upper limb shooting pains on the right side.

An MRI of her spine was recently conducted, and the results were normal. Inflammatory markers were normal with a WCC of 5.2, CRP of 8, and ESR of 21. She was seen by Dr. Sharif (Rheumatology) regarding her back pain, according to whom no structural etiology for diffuse generalized pain-back pain was noted, and symptoms were predominantly muscle spasm. As a result, I am seeking a neurological evaluation for muscular spasm.

The patient has been diagnosed with M54.5 - Low back pain, and I am looking to collaborate with you in treating this condition.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1:

Dear Specialist,

I am referring a patient of mine who has been diagnosed with Nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage, unspecified (I60.9). This patient has been experiencing headaches along with elevated ESR and CRP levels. Imaging tests have revealed a right frontal convexity SAH, and an underlying aneurysm or cerebral amyloid has been ruled out.

I am concerned that this patient may be experiencing CNS vasculitis, and would appreciate your input and advice on how to proceed with treatment. Please let me know what further tests may be necessary, and what medications or therapies might be appropriate for this patient.

Thank you for your time and attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

[Your Name]

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 2:

Dear Dr. [Specialist],

I am writing to refer my patient, [Patient Name], who was diagnosed with M54.5 - low back pain. This 38 year old had 2 previous lumbar decompressions performed in Southampton, in November and December of 2017 for cauda equina syndrome. She presented yesterday having had a fall a week ago and having been to hydrotherapy. On getting out of the ambulance transport back from hydrotherapy she felt that she was wet and had a further 2 episodes of incontinence, once in her house. She did not know she needed to go, could not feel herself going but felt that she wet. She had reduced power on the right hand side 3-5 and on the left of 4+-5. Perianal sensation was reduced. She underwent further imaging which have been discussed with Southampton and Southampton hospital spinal team have requested neurology review. 

As the symptoms are not fully explained by the investigations, we believe that specialist review is necessary at this point. We hope that you could assess and manage her condition accordingly.

Thank you for your attention and we look forward to your advice and support.

Sincerely,

Question: Referral letter: Referral Letter 1:
To Whom It May Concern,

I am writing to refer my patient, [patient's name], a 79-year-old, known epileptic. [He/She] has been taking levetiracetam and phenobarbital for a while now. Unfortunately, [patient's name] had four complex seizures and two absence seizures last night, which have raised concerns about [his/her] ongoing uncontrolled epilepsy. We are uncertain about the cause, and thus, believe that it is crucial to refer [him/her] to a specialist who can further assess and examine the situation.

As an referring physician, I request that the specialist conducts all necessary tests and exams to determine the root cause of the uncontrolled seizures. I urge that [patient's name] receive prompt treatment and care as the consequences of uncontrolled epilepsy can be severe.

Please let me know when and where [patient's name] is due to be seen, so I can notify [him/her] right away.

Sincerely, 
[physician's name]

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 2:

Dear [Consultant Name],

I am writing to refer [Patient Name] to your clinic, with suspected migraine. [Patient Name] has a known left frontal lobe NET that was resected 10 years ago. Yesterday, the patient woke up with an ache in the back of the neck, radiating to the left shoulder. There was also onset of left arm and leg weakness, light headedness, and one absence episode. Today, there is no weakness, but reduced sensation in the left upper arm and left leg (not foot) and headache. The patient has a history of absence seizures and headaches before.

The stroke consultant who saw the patient is not convinced of a stroke and requested MRA brain. Please can you review as new neurology and advise on further management. Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

Question: Referral letter: Dear Neurology Team,

I would like to refer Mr XXXX, a 49 year old gentleman, who presented to our hospital with ongoing chronic back problems. Mr XXXX suffered a fall outside of his GP practice which exacerbated his back pain. A CT was performed in which cauda Equina was ruled out. Although initially under the care of orthopaedics, they are satisfied to discharge from their service. 

Recently Mr XXXX had an unresponsive period in which his saturations dropped to 88% and it was documented that he was twitching. Mr XXXX has no memory of this episode and no pre-warning symptoms. He reports possible similar episodes in the past. Given this episode and his possible medical history, we would be grateful for a neurological review. 

Thank you for your time, 
Allison Freeman, FY1 (General Medicine)

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 2:

Dear Colleague,

We would like to refer 17-year-old Mr. XXXX to you for your expert opinion regarding his lower back pain and occasional spasms, which are affecting his mobility. He has been using crutches for short distances and a wheelchair for school-longer distances.

Mr. XXXX had a viral LRTI four months ago and developed lower limb myalgia and decreasing mobility three months ago. Two months ago, his GP diagnosed him with post-viral myalgia, which he had also experienced two years ago but eventually resolved. Just before admission, he experienced lower back pain and spasms in his leg and was found to be in retention and catheterized, and has been spiking temps with raised CRP, starting him on antibiotics for SUO.

MRI spine was unremarkable, CXR clear, and CK normal. Rheumatology has reviewed the case but is unclear about the pathology. We have several tests pending, including autoimmune screen, C3, C4, ENA, dsDNA, and antiCCP. 

We would be grateful if you could provide further guidance regarding Mr. XXXX's medical condition.

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 2:

Dear Neurologist,

I am writing to refer a pregnant patient who has been diagnosed with R51 - headache. This 34-year-old lady is 11 weeks into her third pregnancy and presents with a headache that is posturally related. Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1:

Dear Doctor,

I am writing to refer my patient, a 51-year-old woman who recently experienced multiple seizures. She had six seizures in total, which started after she experienced a migraine at 8am. Her nieces witnessed the seizure, which began at 10:15 am and lasted for 25 minutes. She had five subsequent seizures, each lasting approximately 5 minutes. During the episode, my patient lost continence and has had right arm flexion and right leg dystonia since the seizure. She has had previous seizures in the past, with 1-2 episodes per year. After such episodes, dystonia can last for up to 5 days.

I also wanted to inform you that my patient's relative has emailed the seizure video to Dr Heffernan and will be in his office tomorrow.

Thank you for your attention to this case, and I look forward to working with you to provide the best care for my patient.

Sincerely,

Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
[Your Name and Title]

Therapy with the ward therapists has commenced, and they are concerned about his neurological and functional recovery. Our consultant has discussed this matter with the elderly care consultants on ICU, and it was concluded that your expertise would be of benefit. We would appreciate your review and any further advice you could give us regarding the care and recovery of our patient Mr. XXXX.

Sincerely,

Question: Referral letter: 

Dear Dr. [Name],

I am writing to refer Mrs. [Patient Name] to your clinic for consultation and advice regarding her diagnosis of Guillain-Barre syndrome. The patient presented with decreased sensation in both feet and stiffness in both legs, which worsened over a day, especially while at work as a nurse. Yesterday, she rang her GP as she felt her legs were weak, and then fell to the floor due to proximal muscle weakness, resulting in hospital admission via ambulance.

On observation, we noted that her hip flex and extension power were reduced to 4-5, while she had full power peripherally. Additionally, shoulder flexion and extension were at a 4-5 level, with reduced sensation in toes bilaterally. After further review by the ICU team, there appears to be no indication for ICU at present as she can produce a good cough and take deep breaths, with vital capacity measurements on spirometry.

Based on her clinical presentation, we have an impression of Guillain-Barre syndrome, and a lumbar puncture (LP) to confirm the diagnosis will be done today. We would appreciate your advice regarding immunoglobulins and further management.

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 2:

Dear [Referral Doctor],

I am writing to refer you to a 79-year-old gentleman who, in 2011, had a previous tissue AVR. A few days ago, on 14.01.15, whilst sitting with a friend and feeling well, he suddenly vomited and suffered an episode of reduced consciousness, where he was unable to communicate. The paramedics found that he had right-sided weakness and admitted him to ED, where he was diagnosed with right arm-leg weakness and left facial droop. His GCS at this time was 11-15, and whilst in ED he developed left hemiparesis. A CT scan of his head showed no acute pathology. Following his CT scan, his left-sided weakness had resolved, but he had nystagmus in his right eye and a left gaze palsy of the right eye. This was followed by an episode of stridor and reduced consciousness, after which he suffered a respiratory arrest and bradycardia. Atropine and Naloxone were given, and he was intubated and ventilated. He is now in critical care, and currently sedated such that a neurological examination is not possible. At present, the diagnosis is unclear, but he has been started on Acyclovir, Ceftriaxone, and given a loading dose of Phenytoin.

I am writing to request your opinion of this gentleman and if there is any further diagnosis that could be apparent at this time.

Thanks for your help and opinions.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Neurologist,

I am writing to refer a 70-year-old gentleman for further evaluation and management of his disorientation symptoms. He lacked capacity and became increasingly aggressive, requiring restraint and IM Haloperidol 2.5mg, which had little effect.

He was then brought to the ICU, where he was ventilated to allow for a repeat CT brain and lumbar puncture, which I suspect could be due to encephalitis.

In summary, I respectfully request your assistance in advising on further investigations and management of this patient.

Thank you for your assistance.

Sincerely,

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1:

Dear Consultant,

I am writing to refer a 17-year-old male patient who has been diagnosed with sepsis of unspecified organism. The patient's previous history includes viral LRTI 4-12 months ago, which was followed by lower limb myalgia and decreasing mobility 3-12 months ago. Two months ago, the GP diagnosed him with post-viral myalgia. Before admission, he complained of lower back pain and spasms in his leg, with occasional spasms and decreased mobility that required crutches for short distances and a wheelchair for longer distances. He was also found in retention and catheterized due to incomplete voiding. His temperature was spiking with raised CRP, and he was started on antibiotics for a suspected urinary tract infection. Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1:

To Whom It May Concern,

I am writing to refer my patient, a 38-year-old male, who was readmitted on Sunday 29th July with worsening numbness and tingling in his feet and legs. The symptoms have now progressed to his perineum and scrotum, with no sensation when passing stool and loss of sensation while passing urine. The patient is also experiencing back pain, and the symptoms began two weeks ago.

The patient was diagnosed with early GBS based on nerve conduction studies completed during his last admission. On examination, there was a reflexia in his lower limbs but good power, apart from plantar and dorsiflexion. He has also lost proprioception and has normal pinprick and slight light touch sensory deficits in his calves but no sensory level. His upper limbs are normal, and there are no visual or respiratory symptoms. The patient is talking full sentences.

The patient runs a bush survival course and walks with a stick in the woods. However, this is becoming increasingly difficult for him. Therefore, I am requesting an urgent assessment for management purposes to determine whether he would be a candidate for IV IG.

Thank you for your time and attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1:

Dear Neurologist,

I am writing to refer an 82-year-old female patient to your care. Mrs. Smith has been experiencing unusual symptoms that suggest a neurological cause, and I believe that as a neurologist, you will be better placed to evaluate and manage her condition.

Mrs. Smith was admitted with epileptic episodes, which were marked by agitation, distress, aggression, and suicidal ideation. Her speech during these episodes was rambling and nonsensical, and she tended to be disoriented. She would be restrained for two hours, after which she would develop a severe headache and feel very drowsy. Additionally, she has developed psychotic symptoms, mostly delusions that people are trying to kill her.

Over the last few months, Mrs. Smith has also developed migrainous-like symptoms that involve photophobia, visual changes, and seeing zig-zag lines. The episodes last for about 20 minutes, and she has no headache during this time. However, they are occurring more frequently, and she was recently experiencing them several times a day.

Mrs. Shaw has no past history of mental health problems, while her family has no history of psychiatric illness or dementia. After evaluation, I believe that her symptoms are more likely neurological than psychiatric. The brief events before admission could have had a migrainous aetiology, or they could be epileptiform. The more recent severe agitation, disorientation, and aggression may be partial seizure activity, which leaves her disoriented and with delusional beliefs that people are trying to kill her.

Therefore, I am requesting that you review Mrs. Shaw's case and investigate her condition further to establish an accurate diagnosis and provide the appropriate treatment. Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Sincerely,

[Your Name]

Question: Referral letter: Referral Letter 1:

Dear Neurologist,

I am writing to refer a patient to you for further management and advice. The patient has been diagnosed with G61.0 - Guillain-Barre syndrome.

The patient presented to us following 6-7 days of diplopia, with vertigo and some possible confusion. She had a 2-day history of headache, frontal in nature which has now resolved. She has no coherent neurology, and initially was reported to have nystagmus on left lateral gaze, then subsequently on the right. Her nystagmus is now not present but she has notable truncal ataxia and incoordination bilaterally, with past pointing worse on the left. She has bilateral arm and leg drift, with weakness in her left shoulder, but otherwise no other focal weakness. She has a loss of left and right eye abduction, and diplopia in the midline with upwards gaze. She also has bilateral Ptosis.

We were initially investigating her for posterior circulation stroke but a CT and MRI head were normal (excluding some inflammation in the right ethmoidal air sinuses) which excluded this. She reports coryzal symptoms 3 days prior to her diplopia starting, but has otherwise been well. She has recently had extreme life stressors with the death of her brother and sister from malignancy (Melanoma and lung Ca) and was restarted on fluoxetine by her GP. We are unsure as to the cause of her diffuse neurology and would appreciate your input with regards to this.

We are going to perform an LP, and are requesting an autoimmune screen, Lyme serology, cholinesterase autoantibodies, syphilis screening, HIV, TFT's, ESR, and paraneoplastic autoantibodies. We would appreciate your input with this lady's ongoing management and advice regarding any additional investigations.

Thank you for your assistance in the management of this patient.

Sincerely,

[Your Name]

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 1: 

Dear [insert specialist’s name],

I am writing to request your advice on a patient who was diagnosed with Sepsis, unspecified organism (ICD-10 code A41.9) and underwent several investigations. The patient, a 76-year-old gentleman, was admitted to our hospital on 14-04-18 with onset of right-sided neck pain, and the pain progressed to his entire neck, and then severe pain at the base of his skull. The patient was febrile at 38.4, with raised C-reactive protein (CRP) levels (which rose to 249), and a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 15-15. No confusion was noted todate, no seizures were observed, and no focal neurology was found. His CT and MRI brain scans were normal, whereby the MRI C-spine only showed spondylitic changes with no evidence of infective discs, and no compressive myelopathy or cord compression. The vasculitic screen was also normal, and the Rheumatology team was satisfied that no systemic process was accounting for his presentation. 

On 15-04-18, a lumbar puncture (LP) was performed on this patient; it was traumatic, with the first bottle being blood-stained, showing the CSF protein level as 1.74, and the cell count being WBC (Bottle 1) <1 X 10^6-L RBC (Bottle 1) 722 X 10^6-L WBC (Bottle 3) <1 X 10^6-L RBC (Bottle 3) 35 X 10^6-L. No bacterial growth was noted on Gram stain. The CSF has been sent for viral screen. 

The patient was commenced on antibiotics for sepsis of unknown origin, although viral meningitis has not been excluded yet. His condition has improved since he was on antibiotics, and since stopping the same on 20-04-18. In light of the raised CSF protein, we would appreciate it if you could advise us on whether to perform further investigations, and if so, which ones; and whether the traumatic nature of the LP, viral meningitis, or any other underlying condition is responsible for the elevated CSF protein.  

We would be grateful for your expertise in managing this case, and look forward to hearing from you soon.

Sincerely, 

[Your Name and Designation]

Question: Referral letter: Referral Letter 2:

Dear [Psychiatrist’s Name],

I am writing to refer my patient, [Patient’s Name], who was admitted to our hospital following a tonic-clonic seizure caused by a low magnesium level after starting Omeprazole 40mg QDS. His CT Brain revealed an increased calcification in the size of the left MCA aneurysm, but there were no other significant changes. He was discharged after receiving IV magnesium replacement and changing to ranitidine. However, since then, his family noticed him becoming increasingly confused with visual hallucinations, restlessness, and aggressiveness, and brought him back to the hospital. After admission, the patient reported having hallucinations associated with a headache. Though there was no fever or speech-visual disturbance, he displayed disorientation in time, place, and person, paranoia, and apparent auditory and visual hallucinations. He lacked capacity and became increasingly aggressive, leading to the prescription of IM haloperidol 2.5mg initially with little effect. 

I issued a MET call and arrived, and after reassessing his condition and behavior, we gave 5mg IV of haloperidol which had a slight effect, enabling me to calm him somewhat. To investigate his encephalitis, he was taken for a repeat CT Brain and Lumbar puncture.

We would like to seek your opinion on the further investigations and management of this patient. Please recommend any other assessments or treatments that you consider necessary.

Thank you and best regards,

Question: Referral letter: Referral letter 2:

Dear Dr. Burn,

We are seeking your advice on our patient Mr. [Full Name] who is currently being treated at our hospital. We would like to know whether further management is required before he is transferred to the Stroke Rehab Unit at Southampton Hospital. 

Mr. XXXX was admitted to our hospital after an overdose of 300mg Oramorph, which caused him to become unconscious. It was discovered that he had aspiration pneumonia, which we treated with IV Tazocin. He was intubated and ventilated to ensure airway protection and ventilatory assistance. During his stay with us, we noticed evolving multi-organ failure suggesting a significant hypoxic episode. The CT scan revealed bilateral lacunar infarcts, while the EEG showed diffuse hypoxic brain injury.

Remarkably, Mr. XXXX made a considerable recovery, although he has little recollection of the events leading up to the overdose. He has been restless ever since, and we have noticed a marked deterioration in his balance. He is still disorientated, with poor insight and memory, and he is perseverating. Although he is responsive and able to name things, he is unable to write and can only manage two-stage commands. He is aware that he has had a stroke, and occasional Haloperidol is needed overnight for agitation. 

Mr. XXXX is eating and drinking and has received input from our Therapy team. He has residual right arm and left weakness (4-5) with mild right facial droop and a right arm pronator drift. His left-hand side has normal power, and he has normal sensation in all his limbs.

Due to his reduced eGFR and AKI, a Renal USS has been requested and will be done shortly. We are monitoring his renal function closely. Mr. XXXX has been reviewed by Dr. Burn, Acquired Brain Injury, and Dr. Ragab, Stroke Consultant, who both agree that he is medically stable for transfer. 

Mr. XXXX is keen to go back to Southampton, where he lives. Dr. Zeun, Stroke Reg, has accepted the patient and has agreed to his transfer. However, we would like your guidance on whether further management is needed before we proceed with the transfer.

Thank you for your help and expertise.

Best regards,

Dear Dr Hilier,

I am writing to request your assistance in the care of one of our patients, who has a known diagnosis of MS. She was admitted to our facility with severe aspiration pneumonia, and her low GCS on April 7th required some time to address. Since then, we have resolved most of the acute problems associated with her admission, including inserting a PEG last week after many failed trials of alternative treatments.

The main issue we now face is difficulties with discharge planning due to her husband's expectations regarding her recovery. Dear Neurologist,

I am writing to refer my patient who was diagnosed with R56.9 - Unspecified convulsions. The patient, who is a 45-year-old female, has been experiencing left-sided headaches, intermittent discrete episodes of dysphasia (receptive), an abnormal movement of the right wrist, and sometimes vomiting. Her symptoms led her to the TIA clinic, but they are now resolved, and her neurological exam is normal. Based on the exams, we suspect an appearance of MS plaques or vascular abnormality, possibly on a background of small vessel disease.

In our recent discussion with the neurosurgical registrar at Southampton, the recommendation was to start the patient on anti-convulsant treatment.
